Glass windows affording 360-degree views on all sides. Horrified Passengers scream as they see the boy and the c The Father takes his Child away from the window. Passenge grab chairs, walls, anything solid, bracing for the impac
Tom and Otis. The train is inches away from Davey. oTis God forgive us.
With a horrific SCREECH, the train plows into the Lincoln dragging it forward as if it were a toy. FADE TO BLACK.

A shabby, wooden shack with a tin roof converted into two offices -- front and back. Laura, four years younger, her hair in a ponytail is on the phone, standing opposite a s window. Trucks are parked outside on the unpaved road.

(into phone) I know the holidays are coming, Mrs. Klein...Jeff personally told me, he’1l be there tomorrow... JEFF STEEL, 40's, potbelly, comes out from the back, head to the front door. He checks out Laura’s behind.
(into phone) ...We’ll finish your driveway by Christmas, I promise... He places a black, steel toy locomotive on her desk. He t puts his hand on her ass. She squirms away from him.
(into phone) -+.Call me tomorrow if they don’t show up...Okay, bye. He grabs her ass again. She hangs up and slaps his hand a
Stop it. I don’t fool around with married men no more. I go to Church now. Every Sunday, Jeff.
(sarcastic) Salvation is near, I’m sure.
You gonna finish her driveway? The old bag’s been calling every day. (noticing toy locomotive) What's that?
For your boy. He exits.
The shabby office is located on a large, fenced lot. Jeff heads to one of the pick-ups. Laura follows.
(re: train) I can't give it to him. Davey hates you, you know.
He doesn't hate me.
You bet he does. He's seen me crying every time you leave.
Don’t tell him it’s from me then.
Who am I supposed to say it’s from?
Make something up. Tell him his dad left it for him. She throws the toy to the ground.
You dirty bastard! You son-of-a- bitch!
For a Christian woman, you got one hell of a mouth.  33. He goes to her. She spits on the ground.
What are you so mad about? It’s a great idea. ‘Specially when you don’t know who his lousy dad is.
Don’t you talk to me like that. He picks up the train and puts it in her hand.

Try and have yourself a nice holiday, Laura. He heads back to his truck, gets in, drives away. Tearful she cleans the dirt from the toy train in her hand. EXT. LAURA & DAVEY’S CONDO, SIMI VALLEY - BALCONY - DAWN The sun burns its way through the pale, orange skies. Clothes hang to dry on the steel railing hemming the bare second floor balcony. Davey puts his black, steel toy locomotive on the rail, sharing the sunrise with it as if it were an old friend. MRS. BROWN, an oddly formal English woman, sporting curle leans over from a neighboring apartment, feigning surpris
(British accent) Why, hello there, Davey. How’s your poor mother, bless her, on this lovely Tuesday morning?
She’s okay.
Up and about, is she?
Not yet, but soon.
If you want me to drop by and fix you two some tea--  34.
(impatiently) Later, Mrs. Brown. He runs inside. INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOUSE - KITCHEN - DUSK Tom enters. Megan sits at the round kitchen table.
What happened?
They suspended me to decide if we followed procedure. (changing subject) You saw the doctor? Restless, he sits opposite her.
Susan brought us some soup.
I’m not hungry. You have to do chemo again? Her nurse’s uniform lie neatly folded on the table.
My scrubs. Won't be needing them anymore. This kitchen is my favorite part of the house. You know, it’s the only room we've fully unpacked.
What did the doctor say, Megan? What are our options?
We don’t have options. We have days, weeks, maybe months. The tumor has metastasized to my bones.
Christ. Oh, God. I’m sorry. Shit. I’m sorry.
It’s okay.  35. He rises and steadies himself against the kitchen counter
We'll treat it again. It’s going to be hard, but--
It’s over.
What do you mean? We've got to fight it. We have to.
I’m done fighting. Chemo made me sick. My cancer is too advanced. And I refuse to spend what is left of my life in a hospital room with tubes, syringes and oncologists.
There must be something--
There’s nothing.
We have to try! We’ve got to find a way to deal with...with...
Death. Say it.

News and camera CREWS swarm in the peripherals recording irritated, confused PASSENGERS who wait in long lines to board the blue busses of California Amtrak. Yellow tape isolates the accident scene from the media. T car, or the mangled piece of metal that is left of it, is still attached to the train’s grill like a deformed, gian bug. DETECTIVES work around it, retrieving evidence. Tom and Otis step out of one car each holding a plastic c with a urine sample. Otis avoids looking at the mangled Lincoln as he and Tom hand their samples to a POLICE OFFI
Let me know if I’m pregnant.
The Police Officer smiles awkwardly and takes the samples N.B. and OFFICIALS from the Federal Railroad Administrati mill nearby under the hot sun. Tom joins them. Otis stays few feet away.
It’s a suicide. No doubt about it. We followed the book. The feed recorder will tell you. N.B. Tom, we know you did. This is a complicated situation.
There are fifty train suicides every year in LA alone. It’s not complicated. It’s routine. N.B. Not with a woman and a young boy involved.
You’re suspended until the hearing.
Some asshole puts himself in front of a train, and it’s my fault? N.B. We don’t have a choice on this one. No one remembers Victor Lopez but everyone knows who Susan Smith is.

What the hell does that mean? OTrIs Victor Lopez -- the homeless man who dived under my train in Oxnard. They all turn to him, surprised to hear him speak. N.B. No one cares about some wacko who decides to end his life under a train. But everyone feels for a mother and her child.
Son-of-a-bitch. Shit!

He walks away. They watch him go. N.B. follows. N.B. (to Official #1) I‘ll talk to him. He’ll cooperate. (turning) Tom! Tom! Wait! Tom, upset, stops a short distance away. He watches the Detectives as they work on the car. N.B. catches up. N.B. We're talking about a week. Ten days max. Let us prove you guys did everything right.
You know we did. N.B. There’s a public image to consider. I don’t have to tell you that every publicized train accident fuels a new Amtrak budget cut debate.

Come on, David. Tom and N.B. turn and see-- Renee, the wiry social worker, escorting Davey to a parke van with the red decal: “VENTURA CHILDREN & FAMILY SERVIC The boy suddenly looks up and clashes into Tom’s eyes. He stares, transfixed. Then, he screams across the way--
Tom looks away, out into the distance.

Fairly dark in spite of the bright day outside. The door opens. Little Tom, 9, barrels in with a tattered school b AUNT ROSE and UNCLE ADAM rise from the dilapidated couch. They’re ordinary Fresno farmers and look it, except that Rose’s eyes are red and puffy.
Aunt Rose!  38.
Oh, Tom... She goes to him and holds him tight, sobbing. Uncle Adam holds his hat in hands, uncomfortable with this blatant display of emotions.
Why are you crying? She's too distraught to answer. He notices a frayed suitc at Uncle Adam's feet.
Where are we going?
There was a fire at the factory Tom, and your mother, well, she...
Mom?
You'll be living with us now. Come on, Son. Rose. We need to be on our way. He picks up Tom’s suitcase and goes to the door. The boy looks around, stunned.
Mom? He runs to the kitchen. Aunt Rose rises in tears. Little Tom comes back in.
She’s gone, Tom.
A sign reads:

Clean and lit, almost homey. PASSENGERS, on waiting-area benches, eat, read and talk. Nearby, Davey, clutching his train, scans the fair chart. One entry on it informs:  39. “SIMI VALLEY TO LOS ANGELES: $10.00 ONE WAY. $20.00 ROUND TRIP.” It might as well be a million. His gaze wanders aimlessly around the station when he spots his answer: SHARON, a pierced, tattooed teenage girl sleeping against a duffel on one bench. She sticks out like a stain on a Sunday sui He moseys over and plumps down next to her, or more exact next to her army-style boots. He furtively glances over. The girl is sound asleep. A wallet sticks out from her ba pocket, attached to her jeans with a silver chain. He inc his way toward her wallet. He checks the terrain. No one notices. No one cares. He gently yanks the chain, pulls o the wallet and opens it. SMACK! Sharon hits his hand, very awake.
Way too slow. That's your problem. Alarmed, he tries to hightail it, when the girl grabs his shirt, planting him firmly on the bench.
I was only gonna borrow it.
(glib) Sure, you were gonna give it back. Think the cops will buy your story?

Please don’t call them. (taking out the quarter from his pocket) Take it. That’s all I have. She glances at the quarter in his hand, unimpressed and l him go. She pulls out a cigarette. He’s too scared to mov
Want one?
You can't smoke here.

Look who's talking. Tony Soprano of Simi Valley.  40. She lights the cigarette and finds a bag of Twinkies in h backpack. She puts it on the bench between them. He slowl reaches for it. She notices the deep cut in his right han
What happened to your hand? He takes a Twinkie, nearly swallowing it whole.
If you give me ten dollars, I'1l send them back when I get to Los Angeles.
What are you going there for? (he shrugs) Come on. It’s a secret? Level with me. You a runaway? (he nods) Mother or father?
Foster home.

(grinning) No shit. Join the frickin’ club. She rises, tosses the cigarette on the floor and squashes with her boot. She traverses the short distance to the ti window. Davey watches her while eating the other Twinkie. Sharon returns to the bench, holding a ticket. She hands to him. He takes it, speechless.
You welcome. It’s good karma. (beat) Well? The last train leaves in five minutes.
I‘1l pay you back.
Tell you what. Send it to my sister. She's in a foster home too. She takes out a pen from her bag.
Give me that ticket.  41. He does -- reluctantly. She scribbles an address on it an gives it back, much to Davey’s relief.
Good luck.
Megan, in a summery cotton dress, gets out of the car and inspects the barely-readable address on this miserable- looking building, ironically named:
Megan studies the rusty mail boxes. She finds what she wants: “Danner. 202.”

Megan carefully advances down the dreary hallway. She get to 202. It’s just a door with grease spots and yellow pol tape. What was she expecting to find anyway? Spent, she leans against the door; it narrowly opens. Someone forgot to lock up. She pushes the door in, exposi the squalid, filthy living room - only years of neglect c do this. She takes in the ruin of Laura and Davey’s life.
Jesus.
(British accent) I fancy they’re long gone. Startled, Megan turns. Mrs. Brown, the oddly formal Briti woman, frowns at her.
The officers. They collected their evidence and left.
You knew them?
Laura and Davey? I suppose so. You look a bit pale, deary.  42.
I could sit for a moment.
Lovely. I‘11 fix us a cupper. INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOUSE ~ LIVING ROOM - DAY Tom opens the door. It’s Otis.

Hey, Tom. Sorry to disturb you at home. Can we talk? INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOUSE - GARAGE - DAY Tom installs a piece of track. Otis, surprised, checks ou the model tracks. oTis I had no idea you were into model trains.
Something wrong with that, Romeo? oTis No, and I don’t need anybody's shit right now. Tom puts the tracks down. He goes to the door.
Let’s get out of here.

Davey climbs up a slope speckled with tall weeds. Somethi moves behind him. He freezes, then quickly turns. Every tree and bush is ominous and sinister. A_lonely bird lands on a branch nearby. It watches him. H stares back.
(scaring the bird)

It doesn’t move. He bends, picks up a small rock from the ground and throws it at the bird.  43. He misses by an inch, but the stubborn thing won't budge even flutter. A shiver runs down his spine. He looks around.

(whispering) Mom? The bird flies away. He shakes his head, dismissive, and continues up the incline. He settles on one spot and carefully sits, unraveling the pink pillowcase wrapped ar his hand. He flinches. The cloth has stuck to a deep, ope wound; it now removes pieces of his skin as it comes undo

It’s a bit like a doll’s house with doilies and whatnots occupying every available corner. Megan, uneasy, is perch on the sofa. Mrs. Brown enters with a teapot and cups. Sh sits, puts a cup in front of Megan and takes one for hers
We'll let it brew a while.
You're very kind.
I've lived next door to Laura for five years. We were no bosom buddies, but you live next to someone for that long, you get to know them in an intimate way.
She ever mention suicide to you?
You ARE a nosy one. Poking! Snooping! How did you find us? Who sent you!
Laura is listed. Call information if you don’t believe me.
Oh, dear...dear...dear... (giggling) Trying times, indeed. Cookies?
No, thanks. Really.
But Mrs. Brown is already up and on her way to the kitche Megan is impatient...
(calling toward kitchen) You were saying, about Laura...
I looked after her son here and there. Bless her. Mrs. Brown returns, munching on butter cookies. She sets plate on the table. Megan smiles cordially.
Couldn't help but notice all the men coming and going out of her apartment. Of course, no one’s been around in ages, but they used to flock to her like hungry birds.
They stopped coming?
She had a breakdown. A nerves disease. Monstrous, isn’t it? The tricks our mind plays on us... Tea?
You think she wanted to die, then? Mrs. Brown pours imaginary tea from the pot. First in Megan’s cup, then in hers. Megan watches her, baffled.
Hard to say, isn’t it? Maybe she did. Maybe she didn’t. (sipping imaginary tea) Quite good. Don’t be shy. Try it.
(beat) My cup is empty.
Nonsense. Don’t be scared, Love. I made it me-self.
(rising) I should go.  45.
You haven‘t had your tea!
("sipping” her tea...) Mmmm... Very good.
Lovely.
Davey looks up at a large sign:

text: A cavernous marble hall with tall ornate ceilings, black marble floors and fabulous chandeliers. Davey furtively passes a tall ticket counter. The two CLERKS inside are b talking. He continues down to one door: “Authorized Personnel Only.”
Davey makes his way down the marble hallway carefully examining the pictures that adorn the wall: Union Station the 30‘s and 40’s. N.B. comes out of one office with an ENGINEER. Davey hugs the wall.
Tough break. Tom loves his train. They go into another office without noticing him. The doo closes behind them. Davey continues down to the--
Davey, holding his train, is face-to-face with a real, li docked train. He runs his fingers along one car. He sees ladder in the back and places his toy engine on the groun

Davey gets to the end of the ladder. He looks down at the tangle of wires and steel connecting his car to the next He steps off the ladder and onto the roof, careful not to too much pressure on his injured right hand.  46. Slowly, he straightens himself and takes a few steps. It’ scary. From his vantage point he can see the gigantic sta building and more trains. Docked trains, resting like bea whales on their track. He continues to walk. Faster and faster. He stumbles, los his balance and almost slips off of the car. Determined, straightens up and looks ahead. He runs. He gets to the e of the car - jumps. He just makes it, landing hard on the adjacent car’s roof his body slamming against the cold, hard metal. Victoriou he rises and looks up at the dark sky.
I’m not scared of you! Do you hear me? I’M NOT SCARED!
Tom and Megan in the cotton dress.
What do you want? What do you want me to do?
What happened to us?
What are you talking about.
You heard me.
Meggie...
Don’t “Meggie” me. I’m not some fragile thing!
What do you want from me!

head_text.subj: I WANT TO KNOW WHY WE NEVER HAD

text: He pulls over to the curb. They sit there a moment, tread on dangerous ground now.  47.
We didn’t find the right time.
You kept moving us around. Fourteen homes in fifteen years of marriage.
That's what trainmen do. They move with the trains.
Not all of them! It’s not a rule. It’s what we did. Who could have a child like that?
You got sick.
You're blaming me?
I‘'m not blaming anyone. It just happened that way. She absorbs his words, swallowing the lump in her throat.
I thought I had all this time. To be a woman, a nurse, a mother. Then I found out I didn’t. Things that weren’t urgent before suddenly took on a whole new meaning.
I was never sure I’d make a good father.
I’m not afraid to die but to think I haven't lived, that terrifies me.
PASSENGERS board the train, passing a sign that reads:
Vince, the engineer, heads to the locomotive.  48.
Davey, washing his face and hair in the small sink, tries make himself presentable. He's careful with his right han that has the nasty, deep cut. His clothes are filthy.
Howie, in conductor's uniform, goes by. Davey exits the bathroom with his train and sees him. He follows.
You the conductor?
(turning) Yeah?
I’m looking for my Uncle Tom.
Never heard of him.
He drives this train.
You mean, Tom Stark? I didn’t know he had relatives.
He has a sister. I want to surprise him.
Sorry, Kid. Tom’s off duty because of the accident.
(playing dumb) The accident? A middle-aged MAN, a bit lost, hands Howie his ticket stu
(to Man) Two cars down. (to Davey) Tell you what, I’1l take you to Tom's place.  49.
Really?
Sure, catch a ride with us. Tom’s nephew is my nephew.

A working man’s joint. Country music plays in the b.g. TR DRIVERS wash down the road at the bar. Tom and Otis are a one table. ROSANNA, cheap highlights and expensive cleava serves Otis a coffee and puts a beer in front of Tom.
Anything else?
We're good. She gives Tom a sultry smile and leaves.
I think she likes you. oTis Not my type.
I didn’t know you had a type.
You thought about it?
About what? oTis The accident. I’m having a hard time with it.
Keep it to yourself. I don’t want to hear it.
I’m going to talk to N.B. I’m giving my notice.
You do that now and you‘ll make it look like we did something wrong.  50. oTis But we did, Tom.
We didn’t have a choice, damn it. oTiIs We didn’t?
If we had put the train on emergency, the wheels would have flattened. We would have derailed.
We'll never know for sure.

No. We won't. It was a judgment call, and I made it. (trying a different tact) Look, you don’t have it so bad. You’re good at what you do. You're barely thirty-five and you’re driving the Starlight. oTis And the guys hate me for it.
Screw them. (to BARTENDER; re: beer) Can I get another?
We killed a human being - a person.

It was a suicide! oTis The homeless man was my first one - Victor Lopez. Tom shakes his head. A heavy weight on his shoulders. Rosanna puts another beer on the table, gives Tom another sultry smile and leaves.
(desperate) Why don’t we talk about something else. (MORE)

TOM (cont'd) . Tell me, what's it like being a bachelor nowadays? You pick up the girls in accounting class? oTiIs It was right before the end of the shift. We had a smooth ride for ten hours. I was looking at the clock and thinking that we were making good time, might even be fifteen minutes early coming into LA. Then I see him. Standing on the tracks, gazing up at the sky, clear as day in the spotlight, and we blow the horn and ring the bell, but he ignores us.
They turn us into executioners.
You know what he did right before we hit him? He smiled at us.

He had a death wish. Some people do. Other people don’t want to die and they die anyway. This wasn’t easy to say. He drinks. Otis pauses, then: He rises. oTis I‘ll wait until the hearing’s done. I'll give N.B. my notice then.
Fine. Do that. Otis does too.
Don’t be an asshole.

I have no need for a quitter. He throws some money on the table. oTis Everything in your life is dying and you just can’t deal with it. Tom punches him. Hard. Otis falls to the floor. His glasses break.  52. He springs up and tries to hit Tom, but misses. Tom punch him in the stomach. Otis doubles over. Tom is ready to pounce on him when the very LA Bartender runs over with a golf club.
Get out! Now!
A strip mall. Otis gets into his car. Tom is blinded by r
You talk about my wife again, I’1l kill you. oTis At least I’m alive. You’re already dead inside and everyone knows it.

Tom, face distorted in rage and sorrow, rises from the fl and looks at his railroad. Shiny model trains sit on miniature tracks. He sends his fist into the tracks. CRASH!! Bits of plastic and metal go everywhere. A plasti “passenger” plunges to the floor. He turns to another section. CRASH!! The “mountain scener behind the tracks breaks in two. A yellow WESTERN PACIFIC model train tumbles down. Methodically he goes around the tracks breaking section after section. He stops to study destruction. The chaos that is his life.
Megan closes a suitcase. She takes a last look around.
Megan carries the suitcase down the stairs. The stark roo is empty except for open and closed moving boxes that are scattered throughout. She knows where to find her husband
Megan enters with the suitcase. Tom sits on the floor margined by his broken railroad. She puts her suitcase do and takes in the ruin around them. He rises.  53.
I was scared of losing you because everyone I cared about left me.
It’s too late, Tom.
I thought if I didn’t get comfortable, if I kept us on the move and didn’t settle down it wouldn’t be so hard if you left me too. She goes to him and gives him a hug. Then:
Walk me to the door? He nods, choked-up, and takes her suitcase. They walk out INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - DAY Megan and Tom enter. He stops.
I can’t let you go.
Tom...
What’s going to happen when you get worse. Who’s going to take care of you there?

I’ll figure it out. A KNOCK. Tom puts down the suitcase, goes to open the doo Davey stands in the doorway clutching his train. Tom blanches and takes a step back. Davey advances into the house, staring at him with accusing eyes. Megan sees them.
Tom? Mad with anger and grief, Davey unleashes a barrage of punches on Tom.  54.
You didn’t stop! Shocked and helpless, Megan watches as Tom fends off Dave blows. She notices the boy’s bruised hand.
(to Tom) Don’t hurt him. Tom manages to pin Davey against the wall.
You had time! You didn’t stop!
Tom! Let him go. He does. Tom and Davey, at a stand off, glare at each oth
Why are you angry with Tom?
He killed my mother!
She killed herself.
(realization) Oh, God.
What were you doing? 60? 70?
I don’t owe you an explanation.
Yes, you do!
Tom. Please.  55.
(beat) My tail was on the curve.
That doesn’t matter.
It does! I was still making the turn!
How many cars?
Seven.
Show him the book.
Davey’s train is perched atop the table. Davey hovers ove Tom's tattered, thick Rule Book, reading intently. Tom watches him, tense. Davey looks up at him.
It doesn’t say.
(pointing to book) Right here. If you can picture a train going very fast--
You mean if it runs over 50 MPH.
Right. And the engineer decides to use the emergency brake instead of slowing it down, then--
There’s a 60% chance the train will derail. That’s what it says?
Yeah.
But that’s not for sure.  56.
It was a chance I couldn’t take.
Because your tail was on the turn?
And I had three hundred passengers. The train was packed. Davey pauses, conflicted between his love for trains and rage for Tom.
It almost always is.
It’s a popular route. Megan joins them at the table with an alcohol rub and a bandage. She cleans Davey’s wound expertly. He winces.
It will only hurt for a second. She quickly fans it with her hand to soothe his pain.
What do they call you?
Davey.
That’s a nice name.
How did you find me?
I went on the train.
What train?
Who’s taking care of you now?
No one.
Don’t you have any family?  57.
They put me in a foster home.
(to Megan) We should call the police. A KNOCK. They exchange tense glances.
If they're not here already. Shit! He rises. Davey looks at Megan, alarmed.
Don’t go anywhere. It'll be okay.
Megan and Tom, confused, stare at two husky WORKMEN. A large, covered object rests behind them. A truck is parke in the driveway.
Megan Stark?
Yes.
We have your piano.
My...piano? (giddy with relief) Of course! My piano! He hands her an invoice. She happily takes it.
Where do you want it? She points to a corner by some moving boxes.
There. Thank you.
What piano?
I ordered it a few days ago.  58.
Oh. They watch as the men carry the piano inside.
What are we going to do?
Get him out of here.
Let him stay.
What?
Just for one day.
They’1l fire me. I can’t have contact with a victim's family.
Did you see his clothes? Did you see his face? His mother just died.
Someone must be looking for him.
Tom, if he’s leaving now, I'm going with him. She returns to the kitchen, leaving him to watch the work as they uncover a black, baby grand piano.
Congratulations. It’s a nice one.
Judy enters. Davey’s not around. She goes to the closet.
Ready to say you're sorry? She opens the closet door. He's not there. Now she notice the shattered glass. The open window... She hurries out.  59.
Davey tries to eat his eggs politely, yet he’s so hungry can’t chew fast enough. Megan, sitting opposite him, smil
More?
No, thank you. Having scrubbed the plate clean, he rises, taking his dis to the sink. He opens the faucet. She watches him, surpri
What are you doing?
Washing my dishes.
I'll do it.
I don’t mind.
It’'s okay. Really.
Tom, edgy, leafs through the newspaper on the couch. Mega enters. Davey follows cautiously. He is drawn to the pian
Do you play, Davey? He shakes his head “no.” Tom stares at him. Megan takes Davey out of the room.
Davey soaks in a bubble bath. His train is on the floor n to him. Megan opens the door slightly.
How are you doing in there?
Good, ma‘’am.  60.

Call me Megan. She puts some clothes on the floor and closes the door. H takes a sponge and scrubs himself. INT. TOM & MEGAN'S HOUSE - TOM’S OFFICE - DAY It's really the storage room. A few boxes are stacked on desk. Others are scattered throughout. Megan covers the futon with colorful sheets. Tom peers in the doorway.
Where is he?
Taking a bath. He's so polite.
Strange kid. Too grown-up. She pushes some boxes out of the way. He helps her.
You can’t imagine how he was raised. (off Tom's puzzled look) I went to see his home yesterday.
Whose home?
Davey and Laura's. In Simi Valley. She goes into one box, takes out pictures of Tom with ste engines and freight trains. He stares at her in disbelief
Why would you do that?
To find out if she really wanted to die.
She put her car on the tracks, didn’t she? Goddamnit, Megan!

It was important to me. A woman died, and you seemed to only care about your suspension... Tom, you should have seen their home. It was awful. Terrible. She places the train photos on the empty bookcase. He tak one and studies it in a gesture of reconciliation.
Where’d you find them?
They've been here. I think he’1l like them. Davey enters in one of Tom’s T-shirts. He holds his train and stands there, awkward. Megan smiles. Without the laye of dirt, Davey is a handsome boy.

(into phone) ++-I‘1l notify the police, Judy...Thanks. Aggravated, she slams the phone, digs in her drawer, take out a cigarette and lights it. She inhales, then:

Crap. Since the desk doesn’t have an inch to spare, files are stacked on the worn carpet. She bends to the floor and fi a folder there: DAVID DANNER. INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOUSE - LAUNDRY ROOM - DAY Megan puts Davey’s clothes in the washer and starts it. S picks up his sad, torn sneakers, wipes them clean. INT. TOM’S OFFICE - DAY The room is neater now. Davey studies a train photo just like Tom did. Megan enters with a mug of hot chocolate.  62.
We better put you in bed. Reluctantly, he goes to the futon.
No one sleeps in the daytime unless they’re sick.
Tom sleeps during the day.
He does?
If you don’t fall asleep, we‘ll think of something to do. He gets in bed, sitting up. She gives him the hot chocola He sips from it.
You're not gonna make me pray?
Pardon?
My mom liked me to pray a lot.
You can if you want to.
Not right now. She caresses his hair.
That’s alright. INT. TOM’S OFFICE - LATER Davey sleeps. Megan watches his every breath. Tom opens t door and peers in.
He's sleeping.  63. INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - DUSK Tom removes a stereo from one of the moving boxes. He installs it next to the TV. Megan takes out a tall vase f another box.
I guess we're staying a while.
I think we will. His eyes drift to her packed suitcase. It still sits by t door. A wordless understanding passes between them. She watches, as he carries her suitcase up the stairs.

Spacious, clean, well-funded. POLICE OFFICERS chat, drink coffee and file reports. Crime is under control in Simi. Renee, anxious, cradling her own Styrofoam cup of coffee, sits with DETECTIVES ANN CRANE and CHRISTIAN FOX.

Judy Neasy has been a foster parent for three years. She has an excellent reputation with us. Alright. She’s a disciplinarian. But I got him on such short notice, and I thought that after...well, after living with a psychotic mother, discipline might be good for him.
I'm sure you meant well.
Do you have a picture? Renee opens her folder, takes out a school photo of Davey hands it to Christian.
We'll circulate it to our patrol units.
You will find him, won't you?  64. Christian and Ann exchange glances.
Maybe you could start with train stations. After the accident he was holding this little toy train--
Renee. May I call you Renee?
Yes. Please.
In 2004 alone, over one hundred thousand children were reported missing in California. Most of them were runaways.
I’m a social worker. You think I don’t know the statistics?

Then you should realize chances are we'll never find him. Never. INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT It’s starting to look like home. Megan, taking a break fr unpacking, sits at the piano. Tom, standing next to her, smiles encouragingly. She makes random sounds softly touching the keys.
I don’t want to wake him.
You won‘t. She caresses the keys with her fingers.
It’s so beautiful. He puts his arms around her full of yearning.
I’m glad you didn't...
I know. I know.
INT. RENEE’S OFFICE - NIGHT Renee, eyes red, smokes a cigarette. Guilt-ridden, she st at Davey's photo lying on the desk. A JANITOR enters with vacuum cleaner. Renee rises.

I was just leaving. Her eyes drift to Davey’s photo. Instead of leaving, she sighs and sits down again. The Janitor turns on the vacuu EXT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - TOM’S OFFICE - DAWN Megan sleeps on a chair opposite Davey - she’s obviously there all night. Tom, standing at the window, watches the August sun lazily make its way up the sky. He turns, meet her eyes.
Good morning. She smiles widely, glowing like a young girl again.
Tom works on the tracks. Megan watches him.
I wish we could keep him.
You promised - one day.
He needs us.
We would be breaking the law. Isn’t it like kidnapping or something?
So?
So?! They won’t reinstate me if they find out he was here even for one day. (different tact) We could get in big trouble!  66.
I don’t care. I’m asking you to do this for me.
If I don’t work on the rails, I’m nothing.
You're my husband. INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - KITCHEN - DAY Megan watches as Davey, in his now clean clothes, drowns eggs in ketchup.
I slept for almost a whole day. I was so tired, and I didn’t even know it. Where’s Tom?
Working on his railroad.
He’s got a railroad?
In the garage. You can join him when you're done.
(jumping up) I’m done.
Megan lets Davey in. Tom works on a broken track section.
Wow! He follows the tracks along the wall, not daring to touch them.
They're broken.
I'll fix ‘em in no time.
So big... Station houses and people and the tracks - they are so real.

Yes, well, I’ve been at it a while. (to Megan) You ready? INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - KITCHEN - DAY With a trembling hand, Megan jots something down on a pie of paper. She folds it neatly and gives it to Davey.
That's our number. If you need anything, just call me, okay?
I don’t want to go back there.
You can’t stay. They won’t let us keep you.
Because of the accident?
Yes. She hugs him. Tom enters and watches her. She releases Davey, hurries o

Megan... She turns to him. There’s nothing he can say to make it better. She leaves. Davey turns to Tom. They go to the do EXT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - DAY Tom and Davey head to the car parked in the driveway. INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - TOM’S OFFICE - DAY Megan, distraught, tears the linens off of the futon. she hears the CAR starting outside. She drops the sheets and goes to the window.  68.
Davey puts on his seat belt. Tom looks out the car window INT. TOM & MEGAN‘S HOME - TOM’S OFFICE - DAY Megan, at the window, watches as Tom pulls out the drivew
A NEIGHBOR, walking her dog on the sidewalk, blocks Tom’s way. Distracted, he brakes just in time and turns to Dave
Put your head down. Davey bends low in his seat. The Neighbor waves, while he dog relieves himself on the driveway. Tom waves back.
What are you afraid of?

Nothing. I don’t want anyone seeing you, is all. He turns to the boy - Davey clasps the scratched toy trai that’s sitting in his lap. It moves Tom. He looks at Dave INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - TOM’S OFFICE - DAY Megan, at the window, takes a step back. She runs out.

Megan runs in, sees Davey and Tom. One look at her husban face tells her everything she needs to know. She rushes i his arms, sobbing. He holds her. She wipes her tears, releases Tom and looks at Davey.
Everything is going to be alright now.  69.
A sign reads:
Clean and lit, almost homey. PASSENGERS wait on benches. Renee tentatively hangs a flyer with Davey’s picture unde the heading:
She looks around, expecting someone to reprimand her. No does. No one cares. INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - KITCHEN - NIGHT Three plates are set on the table. Tom sits opposite Dave
When did you start driving trains?
Many years ago.
How old were you?
I don’t know. Maybe thirty.
I'll be ten in January. Megan, a bit anxious, sets a grilled chicken on the table Tom cuts the bird.
(to Davey) I hope you like chicken.
I do. (deliberate; to Tom) My_mom used to make it all the time. Tom, tense, pushes his chair back, rises.
Excuse me.  70. He leaves. Davey bites his lip and looks at Megan. She smiles compassionately.
You're not mad?
It's okay to miss your mother. INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - TOM’S OFFICE - NIGHT Davey sleeps. Megan adjusts his blanket.
Tom roughly handles the tracks. Megan enters.
He doesn’t know any better.
He did it on purpose. To spite me.
I’m taking the car. He turns to her. Concerned.
Where are you going?
To buy him some clothes. He can't keep wearing your T-shirts.
I’1l go. She looks at him, surprised.
Give me the keys already. You've been going nonstop.
Make sure to get everything. She hands him a list and hugs him.
What the hell are we doing?

I’m not sure, but I feel good. Better than I have in a long time. INT. TARGET STORE -— NIGHT Soft pop MUSIC plays as Tom meanders down the aisle with shopping cart. He stops at the boy’s clothing department. He takes a pair of boy’s jeans from the rack. He adds the to his cart then takes a few more pairs in varying sizes, just in case. INT. TOM & MEGAN'S HOME - TOM’S OFFICE - DAY The August sun bathes the room with light. Megan takes ou new clothes from “Target” bags. She gently folds one of t shirts, puts it in the dresser.
Tom works on his railroad. Davey watches him, clutching h toy locomotive. Tom turns. Davey looks away. Tom resumes working. Davey resumes staring. Tom sighs.
(relenting) Want to help?
Yeah. Tom hands him some “trees.”
You decide where your waiting passengers could use some shade. He goes back to fixing the rails. Davey puts his train as and approaches the tracks.
Careful. Davey nods and installs the “trees.”
What do you call your railroad?
The Stark Special.
Good name for a train.
I like to think so. (re: Davey’s train) Nice engine you got there.
My mom gave it to me. (lying) She was like Megan. She cooked a lot and cleaned and helped me with homework every day.
Yeah. I’m sure she was Mother of the Year. We’re done here. He puts down the tracks. Davey, upset, runs out.
Shit. He exits.
Renee, with a stack of “Davey” flyers, hurries to the doo Her supervisor, AARON, enters. He sees her and stops.
I thought you had a hearing this morning.
Yes, well, I asked Richard to cover for me.
(seeing flyers) What are these?
Flyers.
I know what they are, Renee. What I don’t know is what you’re doing with them.  73.
Going to trains stations.

Come again? INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Megan and Davey, in his new clothes, eagerly sit next to thin, seriously perspiring PIANO TEACHER. He takes out so sheets of music and sets them.
That won't be necessary.
No?
I want you to teach me one tune. Something...simple. He thinks a moment and plays a haunting piece by Badarzew
(moved) What do you call it?

“The Maiden’s Prayer.” INT. DEPARTMENT OF CHILD SERVICES - AARON’S OFFICE - DAY Folders are neatly stacked on the spotless desk. Renee si opposite Aaron. A citation for excellency proudly hangs directly behind him: “AARON LAPIDOS - FOR A DECADE OF DEDICATED SERVICE.”
Now and then we make bad calls. What's important to remember is that we did our best under difficult circumstances.
I completely agree, but--
To say the boy had a troubled history would be an understatement. (MORE)
AARON (cont'd) He probably wouldn’t have made it with any family. Any. His flight wasn’t surprising. It was inevitable. Are we clear?
Very.
Tom drives. Megan is next to him. Davey sits in the back.
You've really never seen one?
They don’t have them in Simi.
They’re large, blue and wet.
(glib; to Tom) You’re such a poet.

The hazy orange sun, hidden behind distant summer clouds, diminishes as it dips into the ocean. Davey, barefoot, ki the water. He turns to Megan and Tom, big smile on his fa and runs along the shore, hopping and jumping on the surf Tom turns to Megan. She looks pale.
You alright? She nods. He puts a tentative arm around her shoulders.

A busy joint on the Venice boardwalk. Megan and Tom, drinking sodas, and Davey, eating chocolate ice cream, si large windows overlooking the ROLLERBLADERS outside as th zoom by. A BAND plays on a small dais. A wedding party, BRIDE and GROOM in tow, enter the coffee shop happy, young and carefree. Some buy ice cream. Some sit. The Bride, barefoot, and Groom, in sandals, get on t dance floor.  75. In their honor, the Band plays a sweet, slow tune. Megan turns to Tom. One look, and they rise and go to the dance floor. Davey, eating his ice cream, watches with a shy sm Megan whispers something in Tom’s ear. He returns to the table and sits. Megan gestures to Davey.
Never keep a lady waiting. Davey hesitates, then rises and goes to Megan. She dances with him. Tom eats Davey’s ice cream.
Renee parks her van at the curb, tosses her cigarette but out the window.

Dirty and under-funded. Busy POLICE OFFICERS work at cram desks. Renee sheepishly pins a “Davey” flyer on one wall. A wall already crowded with dozens and dozens of missing young faces that assemble in a heartbreaking collage.
Tom and Megan sleep. Davey stands in the doorway, watchin them. Megan opens her eyes. Startled, she sits up. Davey backs out. She rises.
Davey sits on the floor rocking to and fro. Megan approac
Davey? You need something? He shakes his head.
Come on. Let’s get you back in bed. INT. TOM’S OFFICE - NIGHT Megan tucks Davey in.  76.
You want to talk about it? (beat) Was it a bad dream?
I was pretending.
Pretending what?
That you’re my mother, and we were like a family. I told Tom my mom was like you. That she cooked and helped me with homework, but she didn’t. Not in a long time.
I’m sure she did her best for you.
She tried real hard.
I know. Go to sleep now.
Megan, exhausted, takes off her robe. She gets in bed. To turns to her.

Everything okay? She buries her head in his chest. He strokes her hair. Sh hugs him tightly. INT. TOM’S OFFICE - NIGHT Davey gets out of bed, holding his train. He goes to the bookcase and carefully positions it on top.
The sign on the front window announces: “BACK TO SCHOOL SALE.” Megan exits with a large bag.

Megan gets in, puts the bag on the passenger seat. She starts the car, then digs in the bag and takes out childr books. She leafs through them. INT. TOM & MEGAN'S HOME - DAVEY’S ROOM - DAY Tom and Davey paint the walls blue in Tom's office. It’s officially Davey’s room. Tom notices Davey’s engine on th bookcase. Davey follows his gaze.
My dad asked my mom to give it to me for Christmas when I was six. He must have really liked trains. (beat) Did your father like trains?
I never knew him.
I didn’t know mine either. Tom takes that in. Davey dips his brush in black and pain a shape over the blue. Tom quizzically watches him.
It's a bird.
Tom watches Megan and Davey play “Chopsticks” together. Davey POUNDS the keys hard. Megan does the same - even harder. Davey laughs. Tom smiles.
Megan enters. A single rose lies on her pillow. She goes the bed and takes it. Tom enters from the bathroom, his h combed back. He strikes a pose at the door. She laughs.
Sexy stuff, huh?
Irresistible.  78. He goes to the bed, collects her in his arms.
I want to be your man.
Silly. You are my man.
Will you be my woman? He takes an elongated box from the night stand and hands to her. She opens it. A delicate necklace lies inside.
Tom! We can't afford this.
Repeat after me: Happy...
(smiling) Happy.
Anniversary.
Anniversary... The years went by so fast, yet certain moments are so clear in my mind.
The first time you talked to me at the diner. He gently lays her down. He kisses her, passionately.
Our first train ride. You remember?

Every detail. I love you so much, my Meggie. He unbuttons her blouse. They kiss. His fingers study her body carefully, like a man discovering virgin land. EXT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - DAWN Sunrays dry the morning dew from the impatiens.  79. INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - KITCHEN - DAY Megan listens, as Davey reads from Jack London's, The Cal the Wild.
(reading) “,..instincts long dead became alive again...” (to Megan) What are, “instincts”?

A feeling you get in your stomach when something is right or wrong. Tom enters with the mail. He goes through the envelopes a opens an official-looking one from the National Transportation Safety Board.
(showing off for Tom) “,..The domesticated generations fell from him...” But he stops reading, noticing that Megan is studying Tom face as he scans the official-looking letter.
What is it?
I have five days. Upset, he leaves the letter on the table and...
I‘1l be in the garage. He exits. Megan takes the letter, looks it over.
Five days for what?
Tom’s hearing. To decide if he did the right thing in the accident.
What if they decide he didn’t do the right thing?  BO.
Then he won’t be an engineer anymore. That’s okay. Tom’s capable. He can do many things.

There’s nothing like driving a train. INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - GARAGE - DAY Tom and Davey work on the railroad. The broken tracks hav been mended. The “scenic scenery” behind the tracks is coming together. Davey picks up a model steam engine.
What do you call this one?
It’s real nice.
Uh-huh. Davey carefully puts it down and goes back to installing “mountain” behind the tracks.
I could tell ‘em she wanted to die. Tom turns to him, perplexed.
Huh?
I could say that at your trial.
It’s a hearing and, no, that’s alright.
You don’t want me to tell ‘em?
It doesn’t matter if your mother wanted to die, what matters is if I handled the situation correctly.  81.
(beat) I forgive you.
Forgive me, for what? She took away my options, when she put her car in front of me.
Yes, she did.
It just so happened that she chose my train.
Yes, I know.
A sign reads:

head_text.subj: WELCOME TO UNION STATION, LOS ANGELES

text: A cavernous marble hall with tall ornate ceilings, black marble floors and fabulous chandeliers. Renee walks past PASSENGERS waiting for their train or loved-ones.

Vending machines, chairs, tables. ENGINEERS, STEWARDS and other TRAIN EMPLOYEES eat, read the paper and gossip. Ren hangs a flyer on the wall. She looks around. Everyone pre much ignores her. Howie, the conductor, and Vince, the engineer, enter. How brightening up, checks out Renee. He and Vince exchange glances: Fresh meat! They approach.
What’s a pretty girl like you doing in a train station all alone? She hands them a flyer. Vince takes it, pretending to stu the photo.
I’m looking for a missing boy. Maybe you've seen him?  82.
(teasing) Oh, yeah. We saw him. When’d we see him, Howie?
(glancing at flyer) Oh, he just left... She’s not stupid. She snatches the flyer away from Vince.
(sarcastic) Thanks a lot.
Sure... The smile leaves Howie’s face. He reaches for the flyer.
Give me that. He looks closely at Davey’s photo. She watches him.
It’s Tom's nephew.
Who's Tom?
The neighborhood is eerily quiet. Tom and Megan take a wa

He said he forgave me for killing his mother. It used to be so simple. There was the right thing to do and the wrong thing to do. I mean, we're talking about trains. It’s mechanics. There shouldn't be a gray area.
Life is a gray area.
Not always. Some things you know with certainty. He looks in her eyes, kisses her.  83. INT. TOM & MEGAN'S HOME - DAVEY’S ROOM - NIGHT Megan tucks Davey in.
Good night, sleep tight, don’t let Davey out of my sight... She tickles him. He giggles.
That's my prayer. You like it?
It’s good, but you’re supposed to say “amen” at the end.
(serious; clearing throat) Amen.
Megan? I‘ve been meaning to talk to you about something.
Shoot.
This girl bought my train ticket to LA, and I promised I’d give her the money back. It’s ten dollars. Megan, touched, is speechless. Davey misreads her express
I'll work for it. Clean the yard, do the dishes, whatever you need.
I’ll go get it.
Wait. He rises and takes his train. He fishes out the ticket st from the toy engine, and gives it to Megan. The address Sharon jotted is on the back.
Send it here. It’s for her sister. She's in a foster home too.
I’ll do it first thing tomorrow. He puts the train back on the bookcase and gets back in b She kneels next to him and kisses his forehead.
(clasping hands in prayer) God, dear God, take care of my mom, her name is Laura Danner, and she sleeps a lot and drinks a lot, but she’s really a good woman, and she likes You very much. Amen.

Megan closes Davey’s door and wipes away tears. EXT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - DAWN Sunrays dry the morning dew from the impatiens. INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - LIVING ROOM - DAY Tom and Davey watch as Megan practices “The Maiden's Pray Suddenly, she stops and doubles over. Tom rushes to her side. He helps her up and walks with her to the stairs.
What's wrong?

Nothing. She’s fine. INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - BATHROOM - DAY Megan throws up violently in the toilet. Tom wipes her fa with his hand. She sits for a moment, then throws up agai INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - BEDROOOM - DAY Megan and Tom lie tangled in each others arms. He caresse her wet, sweaty hair and pulls her to him. Davey sheepishly enters.
There’s someone outside.  85. Tom rises, looks out the bedroom window: Renee’s van is parked outside. He can see the red sticker.
Shit!
Tom! Watch your language.
Department of Children and Family Services. At our door.
Goddamnit. INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - DAY Tom opens the door for Renee.
Tom Stark?
Yeah?

I’m Renee. From Ventura Children and Family Services. We didn’t actually meet, but I remember seeing you at the scene of the accident. (beat) Can I come in? Tom opens the door wide. Renee enters. INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - STAIRWAY Davey, eavesdropping from the stairs, makes a fist.
Thank you. What a lovely home.
Megan slowly rises from the bed. Every move hurts. She pu on a robe, takes a deep breath.  86.
Tom and Renee are seated. Tom returns a “Davey” flyer.
I know who he is.
You haven’t seen him since the accident? He avoids her eyes.
No. She notices Jack London's, The Call of the Wild. She pick it up and opens it.
Great book. Do you have Children, Mr. Stark?
Davey, panicked, turns to Megan. She’s right behind him.
(whispering) I forgot my book!
(whispering) Take my hand. He does. She leads him to her bedroom.
It’s my wife's.
He’s defensive, and Renee senses it. She rises.
Would you terribly mind if I look around?  87.
Megan and Davey enter. He turns to her:
It’s the woman who put me in that foster home!
Renee heads up the stairs to the second floor. Tom follow
He ran away from his foster home.
What’s it to me?
Mr. Howie Pugh? The train conductor? He told me David was on the train, looking for you.
They reach the top of the stairs.
He claimed to be your nephew.
My nephew?
Megan and Davey can hear the approaching footsteps. She desperately looks around, then:
Under the bed!
Renee looks at Davey’s room / Tom's office.
Do you mind?  88.
Sure I do. This is my home.

I'm sorry. It’s a terrible imposition. Nonetheless, she looks inside... INT. DAVEY’S ROOM Davey is a neat boy, as no clothes are lying around. Rene take a quick inventory from the door: Train pictures, blu walls, sheets on the futon...Victorious, she sees Davey's engine on top of the bookcase just when:
Tom? What’s going on? She turns to--
Megan, in her robe, is at the end of the hall. She closes the bedroom door behind her and takes a few steps down to Renee and a tortured Tom.
(to Renee) My wife. Megan.
Sorry to barge in like this. I'm looking for a missing boy.
Oh?

(re: Davey’s room) I couldn’t help notice that the bed in this room is made and the walls are freshly painted. Megan, shivering, leans against the wall. Tom, genuinely alarmed, goes to her. Renee, curious, studies Megan.
Are you okay? Megan nods.  89.
She's sick.
I have metastatic cancer. In my case it means the cancer has spread to my bones. Renee is shocked. Megan's short hair, pale skin, thin fra take on a whole new meaning...
I have trouble sleeping at night. And when I do, I go into the spare room. I don’t like disturbing my husband. As for the walls, blue always cheered me up.
I'm sorry.
(pointedly) You said that already.
(to Renee; re: main bedroom) Want to look inside? Renee, torn, looks at Davey’s room then back at Tom and Megan. She shakes her head.
No. That’s okay. (to Megan) I hope you feel better. She turns and leaves quickly, going down the stairs. SLAM Megan and Tom hear the door closing behind her. The bedro door opens. Davey peers out.
She’s gone, Kid.
Renee reaches for her cigarettes, then crumples the pack tosses it in the passenger's footwell. She digs in her ba finds a business card and her cell. She dials.  90.

Simi Valley Police...Hello... Hello?...Anyone There? Renee hangs up. She looks out at Tom and Megan’s house. S starts the car. INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - BEDROOM - DAY Megan, in bed, holds a thermometer in her mouth. Tom take it out and checks it.
still high.
We should tell him I’m sick.
Not yet. He’s not ready.
I’ll call Susan. She can make dinner.
Don't worry about dinner!
Tom...
What?
It’s going to be okay. He lays his head on her chest. She picks up the phone, di
Susan cooks dinner while intently glancing at Davey and T who sit at the kitchen table.
(re: pot on stove) Almost done.  91.
Susan administers cold compresses to Megan’s burning forehead. Tom, worried sick, stands by the bed. Susan loo at Megan and then back at Tom.
This is the single craziest thing I've ever heard.
We know.
I mean, really.

Yes. It's pretty bad. INT. DEPARTMENT OF CHILD SERVICES - RENEE’S OFFICE - NIGH Renee trashes the flyers in the waste basket. She takes Davey’s folder from her desk. She opens a cluttered drawe puts the file in. The Janitor enters. She shuts the drawe
I was just leaving. And she does.
A green, lush park. Megan, under a tree, sits on a colorf blanket watching KIDS play ball.

Megan! Megan! Look! She turns. Davey, following Tom’s instructions, holds on tightly to a kite. The kite goes high and even higher. Davey, giddy, and Tom watch it go when a strong gust snap the kite out of Davey’s hands. Tom and Davey give chase. Megan looks on as Tom and Davey, further away now, run af the kite. A sharp pain cuts through her spine. She digs i her bag, finds the pills. She dry-swallows one, lies down the blanket, watching the blue sky above.

INT. MICHELLE’S FOSTER HOME - BEDROOM - DAY MICHELLE, 9, sits on the bottom bunk bed. She opens an envelope addressed to her: A $100 bill falls in her lap, then a note: “FROM DAVEY AND YOUR SISTER.” INT. TOM & MEGAN’S HOME - BEDROOM - DAY Tom sits on the bed, holding his head in his hands. Megan puts her arms around him.
You have to go.
Let’s not kid ourselves. As soon as they hear about Davey, I’m out of a job.
If you won’t testify, you’1l never know for sure.
I did the right thing.
Then tell them. I don’t want you to have any regrets. Not because of me. He turns to her and strokes her hair.
I won't.
I‘1l come with you.
No. You’re not well enough. And what about Davey? You can’t just leave him here.
He'll come with us. You’ve done so much for me. Let me do this. I want to.
Tom sits on one of the benches outside large double doors The doors open. Otis comes out. N.B. appears behind him. N.B. (to Tom) They're ready for you. Otis walks away. Tom calls after him.
Hey Otis! You gonna be the sexiest accountant in town. Otis can’t help but smile. Tom goes in.

Fluorescent lights and chairs. Tom’s in the hot seat acro from five ADMINISTRATORS from the National Transportation Safety Board and the Federal Railroad Administration. A f spectators speckle the room: Amtrak PERSONNEL, N.B.
This is an unofficial hearing, Tom. The goal of these proceedings is strictly to determine whether an official investigation is required.
I understand.
For the record, were you Senior Engineer on August eighth, the date of a fatal incident?
I was.
Describe for us what happened that day to the best of your recollection...
A two-story, nondescript administrative building. Tom and Megan’s car is off to one side, at the end of the lot.
I wish I could go in.
Megan, in the passenger seat, clutches her side. She turn Davey, who's in the back, and gives him a brave smile.
Why do we have to hide? Why can’t I just tell the social worker I want to stay with you?
It doesn’t work that way, Davey.
But why? She leans her head against the seat.
People like to follow rules. Us, keeping you, goes against that.
Tom is still in the hot seat.
What was your first reaction when you saw the car?
I went for the emergency brake.
But you didn’t use it.
I decided not to. Nothing would have stopped that train on time - not even the emergency mode.
Your partner thinks the impact might have been prevented.  95.
I disagree. At that speed, on a curve, we probably would have derailed.
